discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
PURGEOLDEXTRACTS: Purges trail files when Oracle GoldenGate is finished
processing them. Without PURGEOLDEXTRACTS, no purging is performed and trail
files can consume significant disk space. For best results, use PURGEOLDEXTRACTS
as a Manager parameter, not as an Extract or Replicat parameter. See 
PURGEOLDEXTRACTSin Reference for Oracle GoldenGatefor more information. (administering-oracle-goldengate.pdf / Page 3-3)

questions.question_text: If multiple GoldenGate processes are accessing a set of trail files, which process should include the PURGEOLDEXTRACTS parameter to trigger trail file clean-up?
You want to use multiple concurrent Extract process groups. What is the key factor in determining how many can be running at the same time?

choices.D: the number of compound keys on the source tables

choices.C: They are checkpoint files for the GoldenGate processes.
choices.D: They are database auditing logs where GoldenGate captures changes.
choices.A: They are a persistent storage area for captured transactions.
choices.B: They are configuration files for the GoldenGate processes.

questions.question_text: What is the key purpose of GoldenGate trail files?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
A is correct
i guess answer should be A. checkpoint files goes in another folder ckpt not in trail folder

questions.question_text: You need to look up table definitions in a file. Which Replicat parameter should you use?

choices.B: You can configure integrated Replicat with two parallel child servers.
choices.A: You can configure integrated Replicat with two parallel apply servers.
choices.D: You can configure integrated Replicat with ASSUMETARGETDEFS and SPECIALRUN parameters.
choices.C: You can configure integrated Replicat with the SPECIALRUN parameter.

questions.question_text: You want to increase parallelism for greater integrated Replicat throughput while preserving the original transaction atomicity. How can you achieve this?
